severe.translation[0].definitions[0].def: severe problems, injuries, illnesses etc are very bad or very serious
severe.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The US faces severe economic problems.
severe.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people usually say an injury, a problem etc is serious rather than severe:
severe.translation[0].definitions[1].def: severe weather is very bad and very extreme, and very hot, dry, cold etc
severe.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a severe punishment is very strict or extreme
severe.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Drug smugglers can expect severe penalties.
severe.translation[0].definitions[3].def: severe criticism is very extreme and shows that you think someone has done something very badly
severe.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: The president came under severe criticism for his handling of the crisis.
severe.translation[0].definitions[4].def: very difficult and needing a lot of effort and skill
severe.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The negotiations will be a severe test of his abilities.
severe.translation[0].definitions[5].def: someone who is severe behaves in a way that does not seem friendly or sympathetic, and is very strict or disapproving
severe.translation[0].definitions[6].def: very plain with little or no decoration
severe.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The blast caused severe damage to the surrounding buildings.
The clothing industry has experienced severe problems in recent years.
She had suffered severe head injuries.
He was in severe pain and unable to call for help.
He suffered from severe depression when he was younger.
Hospitalization is necessary in severe cases.
The closure of the mine was a severe blow to the country’s economy.
